articles.author: David Shepardson, Joseph White
articles.description: Detroit's Big Three automakers and the United Auto Workers remained far apart in labor negotiations on Wednesday, less than 48 hours before the union's deadline to make significant progress or escalate a strike with new work stoppages.
articles.title: UAW, Detroit Three in standoff as wider strike looms

articles.author: Makiko Yamazaki
articles.description: A consortium led by private equity firm Japan Industrial Partners (JIP) gained 78.65% of Toshiba (6502.T) through a tender offer, Toshiba said, coming a step closer to completing a $14 billion deal to take the company private.
articles.title: Toshiba wins shareholder support for JIP's $14 bln takeover offer

articles.author: Aimee Donnellan, Robert Cyran
articles.description: Starry-eyed venture capitalists love to talk about how promising startups might capture a chunk of a giant total addressable market (TAM). This concept can also work in reverse, though. New anti-obesity drugs have the potential to transform public health, while obliterating demand for products and services from the medical, food and fitness industries. Think of them as total unaddressable markets (TUM).
articles.title: Anti-obesity drugs can shrink more than patients

articles.author: Dawn Chmielewski
articles.description: Walt Disney (DIS.N) CEO Bob Iger told investors the company will "quiet the noise" in a culture war that has pitted social conservatives against the global media and entertainment conglomerate, according to an analyst note on Wednesday.
articles.title: Disney CEO says company will 'quiet the noise' in culture wars, according to analyst note

articles.author: Renju Jose
articles.description: Australia's industrial arbitrator on Thursday made recommendations for Chevron (CVX.N) and unions to resolve their dispute on pay and working conditions at the energy giant's two liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities in Western Australia.
articles.title: Australia tribunal makes recommendations for Chevron, LNG unions to end dispute

articles.author: Valerie Volcovici
articles.description: Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced on Wednesday he will pump $500 million into the next phase of his energy transition campaign, aiming to shut down "every last" coal plant in the United States and slash gas-fired capacity in half by 2030.
articles.title: Michael Bloomberg pumps $500 million into bid to close all US coal plants

articles.author: Leroy Leo, Khushi Mandowara
articles.description: U.S. employers are bracing for the largest increase in health insurance costs in a decade next year, according forecasts from healthcare consultants, but workers may be somewhat spared this time around in a tight labor market.
articles.title: US employers to see biggest healthcare cost jump in a decade in 2024

articles.author: Steve Scherer, David Ljunggren
articles.description: Canada this week divulged it had intelligence possibly linking Indian government agents to the murder of a separatist Sikh leader, the kind of news that usually sparks uproar among democratic allies. Not this time.
articles.title: Canada gathers allies as tensions rise with India over Sikh leader's murder

articles.author: Howard Schneider
articles.description: The U.S. Federal Reserve held interest rates steady on Wednesday but stiffened its hawkish stance, with another rate increase projected by the end of the year and monetary policy kept significantly tighter through 2024 than previously expected.
articles.title: Fed leaves interest rates unchanged, sees tighter policy through 2024

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: Blasts could be heard in Kyiv after an air raid alert on Thursday morning, Reuters witnesses said, as authorities sent rescue teams to at least two locations in the Ukrainian capital.
articles.title: Blasts heard in Kyiv, other parts of Ukraine
